alert.note: Alert for Daviess; Gibson; Knox; Pike (Indiana) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued January 10 at 10:23PM EST until January 15 at 1:00AM EST by NWS Indianapolis
info.description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Indiana... White River, East Fork White River. .Rainfall of 1.00 to 1.50 inches across southwestern Indiana this past Saturday night is prolonging minor flooding on the White River from near Petersburg to Hazleton. Flooding is expected to continue until the end of the week. This precipitation event also brought a short period of lowland flooding back to the Seymour area on the East Fork White River in south central Indiana. Flooding should come to an end by Tuesday morning. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT FROM THIS EVENING THROUGH LATE FRIDAY NIGHT... * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...White River at Petersburg. * WHEN...Until early Saturday morning. * IMPACTS...At 18.0 feet, Lowland flooding begins to flood several Pike County roads. Many of the following county roads begin to flood around this level...east of SR 57 include CR 750N...CR 600N and CR 1000E. Pike county road subject to flooding west of SR 57 include...CR 250 W...CR 400W...CR 675N...CR 700 N...CR 1000w...CR 900W...CR 700W and CR 775W. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 9:30 PM EST Monday /8:30 PM CST Monday/ the stage was 16.8 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 9:30 PM EST Monday /8:30 PM CST Monday/ was 16.9 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 17.6 feet tomorrow evening. It will then fall below flood stage early Friday afternoon. - Flood stage is 16.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Flooding is occurring or is imminent. Most flood related deaths occur in automobiles. Do not attempt to cross water covered bridges, dips, or low water crossings. Never try to cross a flowing stream, even a small one, on foot. To escape rising water find another route over higher ground. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov/ind. The next statement should be issued Tuesday morning by around 1100 AM CST /1200 PM EST/.
